Award.AwardTitle: Multifunctional Hydrogels as Stem Cell Carriers for Cardiac Therapy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to Ohio State University is to study multifunctional hydrogels serving as stem cell carriers and having potential to be used for treating heart disease. Existing hydrogels for cardiac stem cell therapy are deficient in that they have low injection properties, limited cell survival, and unsuitable mechanical properties. These limitations compromise efficacy of cardiac stem cell therapy. To address above limitations, the work aims at generating hydrogels that are thermosensitive and injectable with injection properties suitable for delivery into heart by a simple injection approach, have biochemical microenvironment favorable for enhanced stem cell survival/growth, and possess heart-specific mechanical properties. Suitable mechanical properties allow hydrogel itself to provide an efficient mechanical support to heart tissue, prevent stem cell differentiation towards lineages unbeneficial to the improvement of heart function, and ideally direct stem cell differentiation towards desired lineages. In addition to graduate and undergraduate teaching and training, the proposed education and outreach activities include nationwide videoconferencing with high school students; increasing the participation of women in science and engineering; and providing underrepresented/minority students with unique research opportunities related to this project.


Heart disease affects several millions of people in US. Tissue engineering approach that combines biomaterials and stem cells has been used to treat this disease. Current biomaterials for this application have significant limitations, compromising efficacy of the therapy. The work aims to create novel biomaterials specific for cardiac therapy, which possesses appropriate biochemical and biomechanical properties for stem cell survival, growth and differentiation, and has potential to be delivered into heart using convenient, minimally invasive approaches. Successful accomplishment of the proposed research is expected to provide a platform for engineering biomaterials specific for other tissues. The biomaterials research overcomes existing challenges while being integrated with a multifaceted education and outreach plan. It includes nationwide videoconferencing with high school students to allow them to understand the importance of tissue engineering to human health, stimulating female students' interest in learning engineering, and providing unique research opportunities for underrepresented/ minority students to educate a new generation of biomedical scientists and engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Heart disease affects several million people in the US. Stem cell therapy has been considered as an effective approach to treat heart disease. However, direct injection of stem cells into damaged heart tissue experiences low efficacy due to inferior cell retention and poor cell survival. Using viscous injectable hydrogels as stem cell carriers may increase cell retention. Besides, the hydrogels may be modified to improve stem cell survival. Yet current hydrogels are unable to largely augment cell retention and survival.

The aim of this award is to create novel injectable hydrogels that can largely improve stem cell retention and survival in the heart tissue. We have developed hydrogels that are temperature sensitive. They are flowable and injectable around room temperature. At 37oC, they can solidify within 7 seconds to form solid gels with stem cells encapsulated inside. After injection into heart, the hydrogels largely improved stem cell retention. Interestingly, the hydrogel mechanical properties can be tailored to promote stem cells to differentiate into cardiac cells. We found that different types of stem cells require different modulus to differentiate into cardiac cells. However, the differentiation is compromised under the low oxygen and nutrient conditions typical of the damaged heart, due to low cell survival under these conditions. To address this limitation, we have created several hydrogel-based stem cell delivery systems that can release oxygen and prosurvival growth factors to largely increase cell survival. In addition, we found that immobilization of prosurvival growth factors into hydrogels can also improve cell survival. The enhanced cell survival restored stem cell differentiation into cardiac cells in the hydrogels. After being delivered into heart, the hydrogel-based stem cell delivery systems significantly increased cell survival, leading to the improvement of cardiac function.

The developed hydrogel-based stem cell delivery systems may also be used to deliver stem cells into other tissues for regenertion and/or functional improvement. We found that using these systems promoted regeneration of ischemic limbs.

The research activities in this award are integrated with multifaceted education and outreach activities. During the award period, we have participated in Ohio State University Women in Engineering program to educate underrepresented female middle and high school students the importance of tissue engineering to human health. We have provided unique research opportunities for undergraduate students (including underrepresented students), and stimulated their interest in learning engineering. We have also trained graduate students to successfully obtain PhD or MS degree and become a new generation of biomedical scientists and engineers.
